segment.source: Share certificates between apps
segment.target: Share certificates between apps

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that require secure authentication beyond a user Id and password combination can use certificates for authentication.
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that require secure authentication beyond a user Id and password combination can use certificates for authentication.

segment.source: Share certificates between apps
segment.target: Share certificates between apps

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that require secure authentication beyond a user Id and password combination can use certificates for authentication.
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that require secure authentication beyond a user Id and password combination can use certificates for authentication.

segment.source: Certificate authentication provides a high level of trust when authenticating a user.
segment.target: Certificate authentication provides a high level of trust when authenticating a user.

segment.source: In some cases, a group of services will want to authenticate a user for multiple apps.
segment.target: In some cases, a group of services will want to authenticate a user for multiple apps.

segment.source: This article shows how you can authenticate multiple apps using the same certificate, and how you can provide convenient code for a user to import a certificate that was provided to access secured web services.
segment.target: This article shows how you can authenticate multiple apps using the same certificate, and how you can provide convenient code for a user to import a certificate that was provided to access secured web services.

segment.source: Apps can authenticate to a web service using a certificate, and multiple apps can use a single certificate from the certificate store to authenticate the same user.
segment.target: Apps can authenticate to a web service using a certificate, and multiple apps can use a single certificate from the certificate store to authenticate the same user.

segment.source: If a certificate does not exist in the store, you can add code to your app to import a certificate from a PFX file.
segment.target: If a certificate does not exist in the store, you can add code to your app to import a certificate from a PFX file.

segment.source: Enable Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) and client certificate mapping
segment.target: Enable Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) and client certificate mapping

segment.source: This article uses Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) for example purposes.
segment.target: This article uses Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) for example purposes.

segment.source: IIS is not enabled by default.
segment.target: IIS is not enabled by default.

segment.source: You can enable IIS by using the Control Panel.
segment.target: You can enable IIS by using the Control Panel.

segment.source: Open the Control Panel and select Programs.
segment.target: Open the Control Panel and select Programs.

segment.source: Select Turn Windows features on or off.
segment.target: Select Turn Windows features on or off.

segment.source: Expand Internet Information Services and then expand World Wide Web Services.
segment.target: Expand Internet Information Services and then expand World Wide Web Services.

segment.source: Expand Application Development Features and select ASP.NET 3.5 and ASP.NET 4.5.
segment.target: Expand Application Development Features and select ASP.NET 3.5 and ASP.NET 4.5.

segment.source: Making these selections will automatically enable Internet Information Services.
segment.target: Making these selections will automatically enable Internet Information Services.

segment.source: Click OK to apply the changes.
segment.target: Click OK to apply the changes.

segment.source: Create and publish a secured web service
segment.target: Create and publish a secured web service

segment.source: Run Microsoft Visual Studio as administrator and select New Project from the start page.
segment.target: Run Microsoft Visual Studio as administrator and select New Project from the start page.

segment.source: Administrator access is required to publish a web service to an IIS server.
segment.target: Administrator access is required to publish a web service to an IIS server.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog, change the framework to .NET Framework 3.5.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog, change the framework to .NET Framework 3.5.

segment.source: Select Visual C# Web Visual Studio ASP.NET Web Service Application.
segment.target: Select Visual C# Web Visual Studio ASP.NET Web Service Application.

segment.source: Name the application "FirstContosoBank".
segment.target: Name the application "FirstContosoBank".

segment.source: Click OK to create the project.
segment.target: Click OK to create the project.

segment.source: In the Service1.asmx.cs file, replace the default HelloWorld web method with the following "Login" method.
segment.target: In the Service1.asmx.cs file, replace the default HelloWorld web method with the following "Login" method.

segment.source: Save the Service1.asmx.cs file.
segment.target: Save the Service1.asmx.cs file.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the "FirstContosoBank" app and select Publish.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the "FirstContosoBank" app and select Publish.

segment.source: In the Publish Web dialog, create a new profile and name it "ContosoProfile".
segment.target: In the Publish Web dialog, create a new profile and name it "ContosoProfile".

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the next page, enter the server name for your IIS server, and specify a site name of "Default Web Site/FirstContosoBank".
segment.target: On the next page, enter the server name for your IIS server, and specify a site name of "Default Web Site/FirstContosoBank".

segment.source: Click Publish to publish your web service.
segment.target: Click Publish to publish your web service.

segment.source: Configure your web service to use client certificate authentication
segment.target: Configure your web service to use client certificate authentication

segment.source: Run the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager.
segment.target: Run the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager.

segment.source: Expand the sites for your IIS server.
segment.target: Expand the sites for your IIS server.

segment.source: Under the Default Web Site, select the new "FirstContosoBank" web service.
segment.target: Under the Default Web Site, select the new "FirstContosoBank" web service.

segment.source: In the Actions section, select Advanced Settings....
segment.target: In the Actions section, select Advanced Settings....

segment.source: Set the Application Pool to .NET v2.0 and click OK.
segment.target: Set the Application Pool to .NET v2.0 and click OK.

segment.source: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select your IIS server and then double-click Server Certificates.
segment.target: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select your IIS server and then double-click Server Certificates.

segment.source: In the Actions section, select Create Self-Signed Certificate....
segment.target: In the Actions section, select Create Self-Signed Certificate....

segment.source: Enter "ContosoBank" as the friendly name for the certificate and click OK.
segment.target: Enter "ContosoBank" as the friendly name for the certificate and click OK.

segment.source: This will create a new certificate for use by the IIS server in the form of "server-name.domain-name".
segment.target: This will create a new certificate for use by the IIS server in the form of "server-name.domain-name".

segment.source: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select the default web site.
segment.target: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select the default web site.

segment.source: In the Actions section, select Binding and then click Add....
segment.target: In the Actions section, select Binding and then click Add....

segment.source: Select "https" as the type, set the port to "443", and enter the full host name for your IIS server ("server-name.domain-name").
segment.target: Select "https" as the type, set the port to "443", and enter the full host name for your IIS server ("server-name.domain-name").

segment.source: Set the SSL certificate to "ContosoBank".
segment.target: Set the SSL certificate to "ContosoBank".

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Click Close in the Site Bindings window.
segment.target: Click Close in the Site Bindings window.

segment.source: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select the "FirstContosoBank" web service.
segment.target: In the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager, select the "FirstContosoBank" web service.

segment.source: Double-click SSL Settings.
segment.target: Double-click SSL Settings.

segment.source: Check Require SSL.
segment.target: Check Require SSL.

segment.source: Under Client certificates, select Require.
segment.target: Under Client certificates, select Require.

segment.source: In the Actions section, click Apply.
segment.target: In the Actions section, click Apply.

segment.source: You can verify that the web service is configured correctly by opening your web browser and entering the following web address: "https://server-name.domain-name/FirstContosoBank/Service1.asmx".
segment.target: You can verify that the web service is configured correctly by opening your web browser and entering the following web address: "https://server-name.domain-name/FirstContosoBank/Service1.asmx".

segment.source: For example, "https://myserver.example.com/FirstContosoBank/Service1.asmx".
segment.target: For example, "https://myserver.example.com/FirstContosoBank/Service1.asmx".

segment.source: If your web service is configured correctly, you will be prompted to select a client certificate in order to access the web service.
segment.target: If your web service is configured correctly, you will be prompted to select a client certificate in order to access the web service.

segment.source: You can repeat the previous steps to create multiple web services that can be accessed using the same client certificate.
segment.target: You can repeat the previous steps to create multiple web services that can be accessed using the same client certificate.

segment.source: Create a Windows Store app that uses certificate authentication
segment.target: Create a Windows Store app that uses certificate authentication

segment.source: Now that you have one or more secured web services, your apps can use certificates to authenticate to those web services.
segment.target: Now that you have one or more secured web services, your apps can use certificates to authenticate to those web services.

segment.source: When you make a request to an authenticated web service using the HttpClient object, the initial request will not contain a client certificate.
segment.target: When you make a request to an authenticated web service using the HttpClient object, the initial request will not contain a client certificate.

segment.source: The authenticated web service will respond with a request for client authentication.
segment.target: The authenticated web service will respond with a request for client authentication.

segment.source: When this occurs, the Windows client will automatically query the certificate store for available client certificates.
segment.target: When this occurs, the Windows client will automatically query the certificate store for available client certificates.

segment.source: Your user can select from these certificates to authenticate to the web service.
segment.target: Your user can select from these certificates to authenticate to the web service.

segment.source: Some certificates are password protected, so you will need to provide the user with a way to input the password for a certificate.
segment.target: Some certificates are password protected, so you will need to provide the user with a way to input the password for a certificate.

segment.source: If there are no client certificates available, then the user will need to add a certificate to the certificate store.
segment.target: If there are no client certificates available, then the user will need to add a certificate to the certificate store.

segment.source: You can include code in your app that enables a user to select a PFX file that contains a client certificate and then import that certificate into the client certificate store.
segment.target: You can include code in your app that enables a user to select a PFX file that contains a client certificate and then import that certificate into the client certificate store.

segment.source: Tip You can use makecert.exe to create a PFX file to use with this quickstart.
segment.target: Tip You can use makecert.exe to create a PFX file to use with this quickstart.

segment.source: For information on using makecert.exe, see MakeCert.
segment.target: For information on using makecert.exe, see MakeCert.

segment.source: Open Visual Studio and create a new project from the start page.
segment.target: Open Visual Studio and create a new project from the start page.

segment.source: Name the new project "FirstContosoBankApp".
segment.target: Name the new project "FirstContosoBankApp".

segment.source: Click OK to create the new project.
segment.target: Click OK to create the new project.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml file, add the following XAML to the default Grid element.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml file, add the following XAML to the default Grid element.

segment.source: This XAML includes a button to browse for a PFX file to import, a text box to enter a password for a password-protected PFX file, a button to import a selected PFX file, a button to log in to the secured web service, and a text block to display the status of the current action.
segment.target: This XAML includes a button to browse for a PFX file to import, a text box to enter a password for a password-protected PFX file, a button to import a selected PFX file, a button to log in to the secured web service, and a text block to display the status of the current action.

segment.source: Save the MainPage.xaml file.
segment.target: Save the MainPage.xaml file.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following using statements.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following using statements.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following variables to the MainPage class.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following variables to the MainPage class.

segment.source: They specify the address for the secured "Login" method of your "FirstContosoBank" web service, and a global variable that holds a PFX certificate to import into the certificate store.
segment.target: They specify the address for the secured "Login" method of your "FirstContosoBank" web service, and a global variable that holds a PFX certificate to import into the certificate store.

segment.source: Update the server-name to the fully-qualified server name for your Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) server.
segment.target: Update the server-name to the fully-qualified server name for your Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) server.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following click handler for the login button and method to access the secured web service.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following click handler for the login button and method to access the secured web service.

segment.source: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following click handlers for the button to browse for a PFX file and the button to import a selected PFX file into the certificate store.
segment.target: In the MainPage.xaml.cs file, add the following click handlers for the button to browse for a PFX file and the button to import a selected PFX file into the certificate store.

segment.source: Run your app and log in to your secured web service as well as import a PFX file into the local certificate store.
segment.target: Run your app and log in to your secured web service as well as import a PFX file into the local certificate store.

segment.source: You can use these steps to create multiple apps that use the same user certificate to access the same or different secured web services.
segment.target: You can use these steps to create multiple apps that use the same user certificate to access the same or different secured web services.
